A dutiful citizen, James enlisted in the Navy during World War I and served his country proudly. After his honorable discharge from the service, James returned to Maine where he went on to study at Bates College.  James next set out as a merchant seaman. An experience that saw him travel through the Straits of Magellan. After returning to the States, James tried his hand at a number of different ventures, including trading with the New York Telephone Company and eventually entering its engineering division. Acknowledging a real estate boom at the time, James also dipped his feet into the real estate waters. A venture that  was short-lived after the Great Depression reared its ugly head. As the saying goes, when one door closes, another one opens. Throughout this time, James remained loyal to his academy, serving as a member of our board of trustees for over two decades. He would eventually go on to donate his home as well as 30 acres of property to the school.
